Award.AwardTitle: Biomechanical Regulation of Liver Progenitor Cell Functions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Liver development occurs through a multistep process in which precursor cells, termed liver progenitor cells, proliferate extensively and then transition (differentiate) into the mature cell types found in the adult liver. This process is controlled by the microscopic local environment around the cells, termed the microenvironment; many diseases are suggested to arise due to abnormalities in liver microenvironments. Biomechanical signals represent an important component of cell microenvironments, however, it is currently unclear how biomechanical properties of liver tissue influence liver progenitor cell functions. One of the main issues that is limiting progress is that biomechanical cues often work together with other types of stimuli including a broad range of cell-secreted proteins. It is the complex combination of these signals that determines cell function. The goal of this project is to establish engineered tissue platforms that allow for the precise and independent tuning of biomechanical and interacting signals. This work will then leverage these platforms to study mechanisms of liver function that are not accessible with standard culture systems. A more complete understanding of the role of biomechanics in liver progenitor functions would provide an important picture of disease mechanisms. This project will also serve as a foundation for improving engineered liver tissue approaches currently being developed for drug testing or therapeutic applications. The research will be integrated with an educational program developing classroom and laboratory research modules for both high school students (via summer camp modules, where one camp is for girls) and science teachers. These activities have the potential to address societal concerns about encouraging broad participation in science and improving science education.

This award will examine the combinatorial effects of biomechanical and biochemical signals using complementary two-dimensional and three-dimensional microfabricated platforms. Specifically, the project will investigate the cooperative influence of extracellular matrix composition and substrate mechanical stiffness on the hepatocyte and biliary differentiation of liver progenitor cells. These efforts will further utilize recently developed methods that integrate the capability to perturb extracellular matrix properties with the controlled modulation of multicellular geometries and traction force microscopy. Cell differentiation trajectories in parallel microenvironments will be quantitatively assessed using single-cell imaging cytometry. Mechanistic interconnections with biomechanical signaling will be investigated using a compendium of cell contractility mediators and small interfering RNA-based knockdown of candidate factors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stem and progenitor cell functions are regulated by both biochemical and biophysical cues within the cellular microenvironment. To study the complexity of these microenvironments, recent efforts have exploited microfabricated platforms such as high-throughput cellular microarrays to perform comprehensive investigations into the influence of combinations of microenvironmental signals. However, the majority of these strategies have focused on the biochemical properties of extracellular matrix or soluble growth factors, and have yet to broadly address cooperative effects resulting from biophysical signals presented simultaneously by cellular microenvironments. The overall goal of this project was to develop complementary two-dimensional and three-dimensional engineered tissue platforms that can be applied towards the investigation of progenitor cell differentiation mechanisms that are currently inaccessible with current cell culture systems and animal models. Towards this end, we pursued the following research objectives, which were specifically directed at deconstructing the combined influence of biochemical and biomechanical signals in progenitor cell fate specification. In objective 1, we utilized a cell microarray platform to investigate the influence of spatial gradients of Notch signaling and cell mechanical stresses in cell differentiation. In objective 2, we examined the crosstalk between extracellular matrix interactions, mechanical signals, and the Notch pathway. In objective 3, we developed and utilized an arrayed three-dimensional microtissue culture platform to systematically investigate mechanisms of morphogenesis, including the importance of spatial patterns of microenvironmental signals.

Relevant to Intellectual Merit: These research efforts served to establish microscale tissue engineering tools that enable the controlled presentation and systematic perturbation of a range of microenvironmental signals. In addition, these defined cell microenvironments were interfaced with multiple quantitative measurements of cell function, including the assessment of phenotypic marker and reporter expression as well as cell traction force measurements. Collectively, this approach facilitated novel studies into the mechanisms of progenitor cell differentiation, including the unique examination of the combinatorial influence of cell mechanical stress gradients and Notch signaling.

Relevant to Broader Impacts: These engineered cell culture platforms are generalizable, and could be implemented as enabling technologies for fundamental biological investigation and therapeutic development efforts for a broad range of cell and tissue contexts. In addition, this project was interfaced with hands-on summer camp research exercises targeted at early high school students, and was leveraged as part of a developing framework for teaching workshops focused on the concepts of stem cell function, tissue engineering, and regenerative medicine. 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2019
Modified by: Gregory H Underhill
